data.text: Best Way to Carry the Rear Top Bag: Sideways or Long Ways?
Which direction is best to carry a top bag on the rear ? Sideways or long ways ?
How does the ride feel when doing either? Do the one that feels the most stable and comfortable! :)
data.author: James Shaw

data.text: I've done both. I think technically inline with the bike might make it slightly more aero and handle better, but if you have a bunch of other luggage on the bike it likely won't make much difference to your perception of handling...I think the position that best suits daily usage and access will trump anything else on a tour.
data.author: Chris Blacklock

data.text: Doesnt really matter? Longways it gives you better access to sidebags
data.author: Jarkko Eskola
Mhamed Chahchouhi

data.text: This very model of Ortlieb Rack Pack is designed to be attached to Ortlieb panniers sideways 😉 It tends to slide back sometimes, though, you need to tighten the straps every 2hrs or so, though. Having said that, longways may be more aerodynamic and puts the weight directly on the rack, not through pannier mounts. Putting the bag longways gives you better access to panniers; then again for longways mount I’d rather use a drybag, which offers worse access to its contents than the Rack-Pack.
data.author: Marcin Kysiak

data.text: It depends how much you are carrying. I tend towards sideways and use the existing straps to secure it topped up with 2 bungee cords.
data.author: John McDermott

data.text: I agree, I put my rack pack sideways across my 2 panniers attached with 2 long bungy straps. Rarely need to get into my rear panniers.
data.author: Len DeMoss

data.text: There’s no right and wrong here, because whatever works with my luggage might not work with yours. Try both ways and see which seems to fit more securely on your bike, with your rack and your panniers.
data.author: Neil Irwin

data.text: Simple ,either way ok, as long as the front fork is clear of excessive weight ( interferes with steering)...
data.author: John Terra-Nova

data.text: Longways for aerodynamics
data.author: Clive Wallis

data.text: Whatever you want. I always go longways, but that's because I am small and so is my bike :)
data.author: Rachel Katherine

data.text: I would guess that it partly depends on how much stuff (bulk) and weight distribution. With the bag mounted fore-aft As you can see in your photos, if the bulk is not big you can put the bag partially under the saddle. If it is fully stuffed then you can't and this will shift the weight backwards. If the bag weight is evenly distributed in the bag, then the centre of gravity will possibly be behind the rear axle. This will lighten the front end of the bike which will affect handling. Also if the bag is pushed way back, there is less surface area of whatever the bag is mounted on to provide support. With the bag mounted side to side the weight will be further out to the sides, but the c of g will be further forward. And you will support the bag with the panniers beneath it. I put my bag side to side, but that is because my bag is both bulky and heavy. This does limit access to the rear panniers, but all my daily use stuff is in the front panniers or the handlebar bag.
data.author: Mark Perry

data.text: Definitely crossways - You need to bring the Centre of Gravity as far forward as possible to avoid some odd steering issues. Forget about wind resistance. You’re only doing touring speeds and your thighs are hiding most of the top-pack.

data.text: Long way To reduce air resistance

data.text: I place mine sideways and use Rok straps to hold it in place. It never needs retighten and doesn’t slow me down.
data.author: Ty Dawley

data.text: Longways (in line with the tires). It isn't about wind principle as much but of balance. Your wheels effectively become a pair of gyroscopes, by having a load transverse that gyroscopic balance over one of them will cause not only an instability of that "gyroscope" but excessive wear and stress on bearings and other parts such as spokes and frames (torquing), and an increase on your calories burned to maintain balance, leading to premature exhaustion.
data.author: Travis Reece

data.text: I'm an inline guy. I have enough frontal area already. No sense exacerbating the issue.
data.author: Peter Lehman

data.text: Sideways! Weight distribution & i think securement better
data.author: Philip Palmer

data.text: I dont think it makes any difference. They drag (if placed horizontally)is negligible because the panniers are already sticking out and catching the wind. Either position won’t cause any more wear on the hub because it’s the same load regardless.

data.text: Mount your duffel lengthwise to secure your skis.

data.text: Longitudinal: Pro = easy access to panniers. Con = Pendulum effect if beyond back axle. Lateral: Pro = Reduced pendulum effect. Con = Poor access to panniers.

data.text: Definitely in line with the bike. Speaking from experience, you’ll have slightly less wind resistance (it really does make a difference) and it’s easier to access your panniers.
